title: Clan Mackenzie
text:
Clan Mackenzie ( ) is a <a href="Scottish%20clan">Scottish clan</a>, traditionally associated with <a href="Kintail">Kintail</a> and lands in <a href="Ross-shire">Ross-shire</a> in the <a href="Scottish%20Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>. Traditional genealogies trace the ancestors of the Mackenzie chiefs to the 12th century. However, the earliest Mackenzie chief recorded by contemporary evidence is <a href="Alexander%20Mackenzie%20of%20Kintail">Alexander Mackenzie of Kintail</a> who died some time after 1471. Traditionally, during the <a href="Wars%20of%20Scottish%20Independence">Wars of Scottish Independence</a>, the Mackenzies supported <a href="Robert%20the%20Bruce">Robert the Bruce</a>, but feuded with the <a href="Earl%20of%20Ross">Earls of Ross</a> in the latter part of the 14th century. During the 15th and 16th-centuries the Mackenzies feuded with the neighboring clans of Munro and MacDonald. In the 17th century the Mackenzie chief was made <a href="Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Earl of Seaforth</a> in the <a href="peerage%20of%20Scotland">peerage of Scotland</a>. During the <a href="Scotland%20in%20the%20Wars%20of%20the%20Three%20Kingdoms">Scottish Civil War</a> of the 17th century the Mackenzies largely supported the <a href="Cavalier">Royalists</a>. During the <a href="Jacobite%20rising%20of%201715">Jacobite rising of 1715</a> the chief and clan of Mackenzie supported the Jacobite cause. However, during the <a href="Jacobite%20rising%20of%201745">Jacobite rising of 1745</a> the clan was divided with the chief, <a href="Kenneth%20Mackenzie%2C%20Lord%20Fortrose">Kenneth Mackenzie, Lord Fortrose</a>, supporting the British-Hanoverian Government and his relative, <a href="George%20Mackenzie%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Cromartie">George Mackenzie, 3rd Earl of Cromartie</a>, supporting the Jacobites.
History.
Origins.
Traditional origins.
The surname <a href="Mackenzie%20%28surname%29">Mackenzie</a> in <a href="Scottish%20Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a> is "MacCoinneach" which means "son of the fair bright one". The Mackenzies are believed to have the same ancestry as the <a href="Clan%20Matheson">Clan Matheson</a> and Clan Anrias. All three are said to be descended from Gilleoin of the Aird, a <a href="Gaels">Gaelic</a> dynast who lived in the early 12th century. Another theory is that all three are descended from the thirteenth century <a href="Kermac%20Macmaghan">Kermac Macmaghan</a>. The chiefs of the Clan Mackenzie are said to have been settled at their great stronghold on <a href="Eilean%20Donan">Eilean Donan</a> by 1297.
All of the earliest traditional Clan Mackenzie histories claim descent from a Fitzgerald progenitor. These histories include those by John Mackenzie of Applecross (died c.1684/5), George Mackenzie first Earl of Cromarty (died 1714) and the unpublished Letterfearn, Ardintoul and Allangrange manuscripts. It is believed that all of these histories ultimately derive from a single manuscript created by William MacQueen, Parson of Assynt in 1576, now lost. Alexander Mackenzie followed the Fitzgerald scheme for the first edition of his History of the Mackenzies in 1879, but abandoned it in his later 1894 edition based on the intervening publication of genealogies contained in <a href="MS%201467">MS 1467</a>. MS 1467 was compiled 200 years before the earliest surviving Mackenzie traditional history. The Mackenzie and Matheson genealogies in MS 1467, which end c.1400, both derive from a Gilleoin of the Aird, but make no mention of Fitzgerald. The genealogies in MS 1467 have been interpreted as in part a census of the military resources available to Domhnall lord of the Isles in a period when he was seeking to make good his wife's claims to the earldom of Ross, culminating in the battle of Harlaw in 1411. Based on MS 1467 and a series of charters associated with Beauly Priory, it has been suggested that the Mackenzies and Mathesons were junior branches of the Del Ard family, heirs to Gilleoin of the Aird. The senior line of this family, prominent in the 13th and 14th centuries, terminated in the heiress Margaret del Ard, the Lady of Erchless, who married Alexander Chisolm of Cromer c.1350.
In the 14th century during the <a href="Wars%20of%20Scottish%20Independence">Wars of Scottish Independence</a> the Clan Mackenzie is said to have been among the clans who fought on the side of <a href="Robert%20the%20Bruce">Robert the Bruce</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Inverurie%20%281308%29">Battle of Inverurie (1308)</a> against the forces of the <a href="Clan%20Cumming">Clan Comyn</a> who were rivals to the throne. Chief Iain Mac Coinnich is said to have led a force of five hundred Mackenzies at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bannockburn">Battle of Bannockburn</a> in 1314 where the English were defeated.
Later in the 14th century the Mackenzies are said to have become involved in battles against their powerful neighbour the <a href="Earl%20of%20Ross">Earl of Ross</a> and his allies. This resulted in the capture and subsequent execution of chief Kenneth Mackenzie in 1346. Soon after this it appears that his successor as chief of the clan Mackenzie was living in an island castle in Loch Kinellan near Strathpeffer in Easter Ross and it was from this base that the clan was to advance westward once again to Kintail.
Recorded origins.
An early genealogy of the Mackenzies appears in <a href="MS%201467">MS 1467</a>, but the earliest contemporary record of a living Mackenzie is of <a href="Alexander%20Mackenzie%20of%20Kintail">Alexander Mackenzie of Kintail</a> ("Alexandro McKennye de Kintaill") who appeared in two supplications for papal dispensation in 1465 and 1466, and was listed as a witness to a charter by <a href="John%20of%20Islay%2C%20Earl%20of%20Ross">John of Islay, Earl of Ross, and Lord of the Isles</a> on 4 November 1471. The earliest known likeness of a Mackenzie is that of Sir Kenneth Mackenzie (d. 7 February 1491/1492), whose <a href="effigy">effigy</a> can be seen at <a href="Beauly%20Priory">Beauly Priory</a>. He is the first "Mackenzie" to be buried at Beauly Priory. There is no reliable evidence to support the traditional assertion that previous members of his family were buried at <a href="Iona">Iona</a>.
15th century and clan conflicts.
In 1452 a force of tribes loyal to Mackenzie of Kintail took hostage a relative of the <a href="Earl%20of%20Ross">Earl of Ross</a>. This resulted in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bealach%20nam%20Broig">Battle of Bealach nam Broig</a> which was fought to the north-west of <a href="Ben%20Wyvis">Ben Wyvis</a>. The <a href="Clan%20Munro">Clan Munro</a> and their <a href="septs">septs</a> the Dingwalls rescued the Ross hostage but won a hollow victory, with a great loss of their own men.
In 1488 the Clan Mackenzie fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Sauchieburn">Battle of Sauchieburn</a> led by <a href="Hector%20Roy%20Mackenzie">Hector Roy Mackenzie</a> but after the defeat of the King's forces there, Hector narrowly escaped, returning to Ross-shire where he took <a href="Redcastle">Redcastle</a> from the <a href="Clan%20Rose">Clan Rose</a>, for the rebels.
In 1491 the <a href="Battle%20of%20Blar%20Na%20Pairce">Battle of Blar Na Pairce</a> was fought between the Mackenzies and the MacDonalds. This was followed by the <a href="Raid%20on%20Ross">Raid on Ross</a> also in 1491 when the Clan Mackenzie clashed with a number of clans including the <a href="Clan%20MacDonald%20of%20Lochalsh">Clan MacDonald of Lochalsh</a>, <a href="Clan%20MacDonald%20of%20Clanranald">Clan MacDonald of Clanranald</a>, <a href="Clan%20Cameron">Clan Cameron</a> and the <a href="Chattan%20Confederation">Chattan Confederation</a> of <a href="Clan%20Mackintosh">Clan Mackintosh</a>.
In 1497 <a href="Clan%20MacDonald%20of%20Lochalsh">Alexander MacDonald of Lochalsh</a> and his clan rebelled against the King. MacDonald invaded the fertile lands of Ross-shire where he was defeated in battle by the Mackenzies at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Drumchatt%20%281497%29">Battle of Drumchatt (1497)</a>, after which he was driven out of Ross-shire.
16th century and clan conflicts.
During the <a href="Anglo-Scottish%20Wars">Anglo-Scottish Wars</a> <a href="John%20Mackenzie%2C%209th%20of%20Kintail">John Mackenzie, 9th of Kintail</a> led the clan at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Flodden">Battle of Flodden</a> in 1513. John was lucky enough to escape but many of his followers lost their lives. John Mackenzie also fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Pinkie%20Cleugh">Battle of Pinkie Cleugh</a> in 1547 where he was captured by the English. However, his clan paid a ransom of cows for his release.
The growing importance of the Clan Mackenzie was vividly demonstrated in 1544 when the <a href="Earl%20of%20Huntly">Earl of Huntly</a>, the Lieutenant of the North, commanded chief John Mackenzie to raise his clan against <a href="Clan%20MacDonald%20of%20Clan%20Ranald">Clan Ranald</a> of Moidart. The Mackenzie chief refused and Huntly's supporters, the Clan Grant, Clan Ross and Clan Mackintosh declined to attack the Mackenzies. From that time the Mackenzies were recognised as a separate and superior force in the north-west.
On 13 December 1545 at <a href="Dingwall">Dingwall</a>, the <a href="Earl%20of%20Sutherland">Earl of Sutherland</a> entered into a bond of <a href="manrent">manrent</a> with John Mackenzie of Kintail for mutual defence against all enemies, reserving only their allegiance to the youthful <a href="Mary%2C%20Queen%20of%20Scots">Mary, Queen of Scots</a>. At the <a href="Battle%20of%20Langside">Battle of Langside</a> in 1568 the Mackenzies fought on the side of Mary, Queen of Scots, against the forces of her half-brother <a href="James%20Stewart%2C%20Earl%20of%20Moray">James Stewart, Earl of Moray</a>. Their chief, <a href="Kenneth%20Mackenzie%2C%2010th%20of%20Kintail">Kenneth Mackenzie, 10th of Kintail</a> died soon afterwards.
In 1570 a feud broke out with the Munros over the <a href="Castle%20Chanonry%20of%20Ross">Castle Chanonry of Ross</a>. Andrew Munro of Milntown defended it for 3 years against the Clan Mackenzie, at the expense of many lives on both sides. The feud was settled when the castle was handed over to the Mackenzies by an "Act of Pacification". In 1597 the <a href="Battle%20of%20Logiebride">Battle of Logiebride</a> took place between the Mackenzies and MacLeods of Rassay against the Munros and the <a href="Bain%20family">Bain family</a> of <a href="Tulloch%20Castle">Tulloch Castle</a>.
17th century and Civil War.
By the beginning of the 17th century the territory of the Mackenzies extended from the <a href="Black%20Isle">Black Isle</a> in the east to the <a href="Outer%20Hebrides">Outer Hebrides</a> in the west. They took over the <a href="Isle%20of%20Lewis">Isle of Lewis</a> from its former <a href="Clan%20MacLeod%20of%20Lewis">Clan MacLeod of Lewis</a> rulers and also <a href="Loch%20Alsh">Loch Alsh</a> from the MacDonells. The <a href="Battle%20of%20Morar">Battle of Morar</a> in 1602 was fought between the Clan Mackenzie and <a href="Clan%20MacDonell%20of%20Glengarry">Clan MacDonell of Glengarry</a>.
In 1623, the clan chief <a href="Colin%20Mackenzie%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Colin Mackenzie</a> was made <a href="Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Earl of Seaforth</a>, a title in the <a href="peerage">peerage</a> of <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>, taking his title from a sea loch on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Lewis">Isle of Lewis</a>.
In 1645, Lord Seaforth, fighting as a <a href="Covenanter">Covenanter</a>, led a force against the royalist <a href="James%20Graham%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Montrose">James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose</a>, at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Auldearn">Battle of Auldearn</a> where the Covenanters were defeated. Montrose followed up his success by destroying many houses that belonged to people who had opposed the royalist cause, including that of Thomas Mackenzie of Pluscardine. Later in 1649 Thomas Mackenzie of Pluscardine adopted the royalist cause and led his own uprising in the <a href="Siege%20of%20Inverness%20%281649%29">Siege of Inverness (1649)</a>.
In 1672, the Mackenzies were granted a commission of "<a href="Commission%20of%20Justiciary">fire and sword</a>" against the <a href="Clan%20MacLeod%20of%20Lewis%23Branches%20of%20the%20clan">MacLeods of Assynt</a> who were a branch of the Clan MacLeod of Lewis and were seated at <a href="Ardvreck%20Castle">Ardvreck Castle</a>, which was attacked and captured by the Mackenzies, who took control of the lands of <a href="Assynt">Assynt</a>.
In 1688, <a href="Kenneth%20Mackenzie%20of%20Suddie">Kenneth Mackenzie of Suddie</a> was killed leading a Government-backed <a href="Independent%20Highland%20Companies">Independent Highland Company</a> in support of Mackintosh of Mackintosh against the <a href="Clan%20MacDonald%20of%20Keppoch">Clan MacDonald of Keppoch</a> who were supported by the <a href="Clan%20Cameron">Clan Cameron</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Mulroy">Battle of Mulroy</a>. During the <a href="Williamite%20War%20in%20Ireland">Williamite War in Ireland</a> the Clan Mackenzie (led by their chief <a href="Kenneth%20Mackenzie%2C%204th%20Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Kenneth Mackenzie, 4th Earl of Seaforth</a>) are believed to have supported King James at the <a href="Siege%20of%20Derry">Siege of Derry</a> and the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Boyne">Battle of the Boyne</a> in 1690.
18th century and Jacobite risings.
During the <a href="Jacobite%20rising%20of%201715">Jacobite rising of 1715</a> chief <a href="William%20Mackenzie%2C%205th%20Earl%20of%20Seaforth">William Mackenzie, 5th Earl of Seaforth</a> led the Clan Mackenzie in support of the Jacobite rebels. However, during the <a href="Jacobite%20rising%20of%201745">Jacobite rising of 1745</a> the Clan Mackenzie was divided: The chief, <a href="Kenneth%20Mackenzie%2C%20Lord%20Fortrose">Kenneth Mackenzie, Lord Fortrose</a>, did not support the Jacobites and raised several <a href="Independent%20Highland%20Companies">Independent Highland Companies</a> from the Clan Mackenzie to support the British Government. However, during the 1745 rising a large part of the Clan Mackenzie followed the chief's cousin, <a href="George%20Mackenzie%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Cromartie">George Mackenzie, 3rd Earl of Cromartie</a> who was a Jacobite.
1715 and 1719 Jacobite risings.
In what is known as the <a href="Skirmish%20of%20Alness">Skirmish of Alness</a> in 1715 the <a href="Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Earl of Seaforth</a>, chief of Mackenzie led a force of 3000 men that forced the retreat of a smaller force loyal to the British Government, which was commanded by the <a href="Earl%20of%20Sutherland">Earl of Sutherland</a> and included the clans Sutherland, Munro, Ross and Mackay. Much of the Ross's and Munro's lands were ravaged, but they retaliated by raiding the Mackenzie lands in what is known as the <a href="Siege%20of%20Brahan">Siege of Brahan</a>.
The <a href="Siege%20of%20Inverness%20%281715%29">Siege of Inverness (1715)</a> came to an end when the town, which was being held by the Mackenzies was surrendered to Simon Fraser of Lovat. Soon after this Colonel <a href="Sir%20Robert%20Munro%2C%206th%20Baronet">Sir Robert Munro, 6th Baronet</a> of Foulis marched into the town of <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a> with 400 Munros and took over control as governor from Fraser. Government troops arrived in Inverness towards the end of February, and for some months the process of disarming the rebels went on, led by a Munro detachment under George Munro of Culcairn.
The clan rivalries which had erupted in rebellion were finding an outlet in local politics. The Mackenzie's position as Earl of Seaforth came to an end in 1716, and it seems to have been arranged that while the <a href="Clan%20Ross">Clan Ross</a> held the county seat the Munros would represent the <a href="Tain%20Burghs%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Tain Burghs</a>. To secure the burghs, control of three out of the five was necessary. Ross ascendancy was secure in Tain, and from 1716 to 1745 the Munros controlled <a href="Dingwall">Dingwall</a>.
The Clan Mackenzie fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Glen%20Shiel">Battle of Glen Shiel</a> in 1719 where they were defeated by Government forces and the Mackenzie chief was wounded, afterwards retreating to the Western Isles and from there to the Continent. In 1721 the Clan Mackenzie, led by <a href="Murchison%20%28sept%29">Donald Murchison</a>, defeated Government supporters from the <a href="Clan%20Ross">Clan Ross</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Glen%20Affric">Battle of Glen Affric</a>. This was followed by the <a href="Battle%20of%20Coille%20Bhan">Battle of Coille Bhan</a> where again, led by Donald Murchison and also his relative Kenneth Murchison, the Clan Mackenzie defeated Government forces. <a href="General%20Wade">General Wade</a>'s report on the Highlands in 1724, estimated the clan strength at 3,000 men.
1745 Jacobite rising.
<a href="George%20Mackenzie%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Cromartie">George Mackenzie, 3rd Earl of Cromartie</a> led the Jacobite Mackenzies at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Falkirk%20%281746%29">Battle of Falkirk (1746)</a> where they were victorious in helping to defeat British Government forces. The Mackenzies then went on to lay waste to the lands of the Munros who supported the Government and burn down <a href="Foulis%20Castle">Foulis Castle</a>. They also went on to lay waste to the lands of the <a href="Clan%20Sutherland">Clan Sutherland</a> and the <a href="Earl%20of%20Sutherland">Earl of Sutherland</a> who also supported the Government, and captured <a href="Dunrobin%20Castle">Dunrobin Castle</a>, although the Earl of Sutherland himself escaped through a back door. However, soon after this as the <a href="Earl%20of%20Cromartie">Earl of Cromartie</a> and his forces were travelling south to meet <a href="Charles%20Edward%20Stuart">Charles Edward Stuart</a> they were attacked by the Mackay and Sutherland Independent Highland Companies who supported the British Government in what became known as the <a href="Battle%20of%20Littleferry">Battle of Littleferry</a> and the Jacobite Mackenzies were prevented from joining the Jacobite army at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Culloden">Battle of Culloden</a>. Soon after George Mackenzie, 3rd Earl of Cromartie and his son were captured at <a href="Dunrobin%20Castle">Dunrobin Castle</a>. The Earl of Cromartie's titles were then forfeited.
Other Mackenzies took the side of the British Government: the chief, Kenneth Mackenzie, Lord Fortrose had in fact raised three <a href="Independent%20Highland%20Companies">Independent Highland Companies</a> to support the British Government. In one of the Independent Highland Companies under Captain Colin Mackenzie it is recorded at Shiramore in Badenoch in June 1746 and it included many of them from Kintail as well as more than sixty men from the <a href="Clan%20MacRae">Clan MacRae</a>.
War, France, and India.
A number of famous regiments have been raised from the Mackenzie clan, including the Highland Light Infantry (raised in 1777), the Seaforth Highlanders (raised in 1778), and the second battalion of the Seaforth Highlanders, known as the Ross-shire Buffs (raised in 1793). All those regiments wore the MacKenzie tartan. Born in 1754, Chief <a href="Francis%20Mackenzie%2C%201st%20Baron%20Seaforth">Francis Mackenzie, 1st Baron Seaforth</a>, the last Lord Seaforth raised a regiment for the British Army in 1778, the 72nd, and the clan produced another the 78th in 1793. Both had distinguished records fighting against <a href="Napoleon%20I%20of%20France">Napoleon</a> and were later amalgamated into the <a href="Queen%27s%20Own%20Highlanders">Queen's Own Highlanders</a>.
The 78th Regiment, as it was first called, was raised in 1778 from men on the Seaforth and other Mackenzie estates. The Earl of Seaforth, having raised his men, sailed with them to India in 1781, but died there a few months later. During the Wars in India, <a href="Colin%20Mackenzie">Colin Mackenzie</a> (1754–1821) was Surveyor General of India, and an art collector and orientalist. He produced many of the first accurate maps of India, and his research and collections contributed significantly to the field of Asian studies. In 1799, he was part of the British force at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Seringapatam">Battle of Seringapatam</a>. He also fought in the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>.
Modern history.
Throughout the 19th century Clan Mackenzie was without a chief that was recognised by the <a href="Lord%20Lyon%20King%20of%20Arms">Lord Lyon King of Arms</a>. In 1979, Roderick Grant Francis Blunt-Mackenzie, 4th Earl of Cromartie, legally changed his surname to "Mackenzie" and was widely recognised as Chief of the clan (for example by Clan Mackenzie Societies around the Commonwealth). Although not descended from a "Mackenzie" in the male line (his father was born a "Blunt" and later changed to "Blunt-Mackenzie" after marrying Sibell Lilian Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, Countess of Cromartie) he inherited his titles and "Mackenzie" descent through his mother (even she only claims a "Mackenzie" descent as a great-great-great-great-granddaughter of <a href="George%20Mackenzie%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Cromartie">George Mackenzie, 3rd Earl of Cromartie</a>). On his death in 1990 his son John Ruaridh Mackenzie, 5th Earl of Cromartie succeeded as chief of Clan Mackenzie. The Earl of Cromartie still owns lands in "clan country" however, the largest remaining Mackenzie landowner by some margin is Mackenzie of <a href="Gairloch">Gairloch</a>, with an estate which extends to over 50,000 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (like the clan chief, Mackenzie of Gairloch has inherited his clan name and lands through the female line). The current chief is a member of the <a href="Standing%20Council%20of%20Scottish%20Chiefs">Standing Council of Scottish Chiefs</a>.
The current chief of Clan Mackenzie lives at <a href="Castle%20Leod">Castle Leod</a>, which is thought to date from the 16th century. The chief has leased the unoccupied old tower to the Clan Mackenzie Charitable Trust (CMCT) for 99 years. In 1991 it was announced that the castle was planned to be restored. The restoration was to include a clan genealogical centre that would be open to the public. During the 1990s there was extensive work done on the tower. In 2002 the Highland Buildings Preservation Trust (HBPT) was contacted, to carry out a feasibility study to investigate the potential for the re-use of the upper floor space of the tower, which deemed public funding to be sought to cover the costs of restoration. Because of concerns of physical and legal separation between the clan chief and the tower, the chief decided that the conditions of public funding were too onerous.
Chief.
<a href="Scottish%20clan%20chief">Clan chief</a>: <a href="John%20Mackenzie%2C%205th%20Earl%20of%20Cromartie">John Ruaridh Grant Mackenzie</a>, <a href="Earl%20of%20Cromartie">5th Earl of Cromartie</a> (b. 1948), Viscount Tarbat of Tarbat, Baron Castlehaven, Baron MacLeod of Castle Leod, Chief of Clan Mackenzie. Chiefs of Clan Mackenzie are titled as "Caberféidh" (translation from Scottish Gaelic: "Deer's antlers"). This Gaelic title is derived from the <a href="stag">stag's</a> head charge on the former chief, the <a href="Earl%20of%20Seaforth">Earl of Seaforth</a>'s <a href="Coat%20of%20Arms">Coat of Arms</a>.

Origin of the name.
The surname "<a href="Mackenzie%20%28surname%29">Mackenzie</a>" is of Scottish origin and derived from <a href="Scottish%20Gaelic">Gaelic</a>. The name is an <a href="Anglicised">Anglicised</a> form of the Gaelic "Mac Coinnich", which is a <a href="patronymic">patronymic</a> form of the <a href="personal%20name">personal name</a> "Coinneach" meaning "comely" or "handsome". Today personal name "Coinneach" is generally Anglicised as "<a href="Kenneth">Kenneth</a>" however "Kenneth" was originally used as an Anglicisation of different Gaelic personal name – "Cionaodh".
The Anglicised "Mackenzie" had originally been pronounced "Mackaingye" – with a modern <a href="English%20language">English</a> "<a href="Y">Y</a>" sound represented with the letter <a href="yogh">yogh</a> . In the 18th century it became popular to write and pronounce the name with what is the equivalent of a modern English "<a href="Z">Z</a>" sound, because of the similarity of the letter "yogh" and letter "Z". There are <a href="Scots%20language">Lowland Scots</a> words and Scottish names that have been affected in a similar way (example: the surname "<a href="Menzies">Menzies</a>").
In fiction.
Fictional Mackenzies appear in the <a href="Outlander%20series">Outlander series</a> of books by <a href="Diana%20Gabaldon">Diana Gabaldon</a>.
The Seat of the Clan Mackenzie, <a href="Castle%20Leod">Castle Leod</a> is widely considered to be the inspiration behind Castle Leoch, the home of the Clan Mackenzie, in Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series. It was considered as a filming location for the TV series, however, <a href="Doune%20Castle">Doune Castle</a> was selected due to its ease of location. This may be surprising to viewers who know Castle Leod as the seat of the Clan Mackenzie and accurately represents the historical period which Diana Gabaldon seeks to portray.
Diana Gabaldon told STV that "When the TV show began scouting locations, I suggested Leod as a possibility. It's entirely accurate as to period, of course, and has magnificent grounds, with a park of enormous, exotic trees planted by centuries of MacKenzies and their visitors. (Diana herself planted a "very modest" rowan, as her "own wee contribution" to the history).
In the <a href="Emberverse%20series">Emberverse series</a> by <a href="S.M.%20Stirling">S.M. Stirling</a>, otherwise known as the 'Change' world, the founder of the Clan Mackenzie, Juniper Mackenzie, is descended from this Scottish clan.
